{"step_by_step_thinking": "The relevant documents seem to be case studies of various medical conditions. Non-union of fractures, open external subtalus dislocation, firearm injury, unusual location of oxyurids, and cyclotropia are the topics discussed. None of these cases directly relate to intrafusal fibres or their contractile parts. However, one type of fibre mentioned in the field of ophthalmology is extrafusal muscle spindle. Therefore, it's reasonable to assume that intrafusal fibres would also have a similar structure and function.
